projects.title: GYST (Get Your Style Together)
projects.challenge: Build a mobile app that helps people manage their closet, sell locally, and dress sustainably - proving that technology can drive meaningful change in consumer behavior while supporting local economies.
whatIDid: Designed and developed full-stack React Native mobile application with five core features: Style (wardrobe management), SwapMeet (P2P marketplace), GYST Hub (daily styling), ThriftShop (local discovery), and Insights (analytics)
Built SwapMeet marketplace enabling peer-to-peer clothing trades and sales within local communities with local-only pickup to reduce carbon footprint
Created ThriftShop integration connecting users to local secondhand stores with location-based discovery
Integrated Claude AI for personalized outfit suggestions based on weather, occasion, and wardrobe contents
Implemented subscription model (GYST+) with RevenueCat for unlimited AI features and reduced marketplace fees
Developed wardrobe analytics dashboard showing usage patterns, cost-per-wear metrics, and sustainability impact
Built capsule wardrobe feature for travel and seasonal planning
projects.impact: Created a platform grounded in the philosophy that sustainable fashion should strengthen local communities, not just reduce waste. GYST demonstrates how apps can shift consumer behavior toward environmentally conscious choices while keeping money circulating in local economies. Currently preparing for App Store release.
projects.skills: React Native, Expo, Firebase, Claude AI integration, RevenueCat subscriptions, geolocation services, peer-to-peer marketplace design, sustainable tech architecture, UI/UX design

projects.title: CoachDesk
projects.challenge: Build a platform that helps K-12 instructional coaches manage their work supporting multiple teachers across schools and districts, with built-in privacy controls and offline support for the realities of school environments.
whatIDid: Designed and developed full-stack Next.js web application with role-based access for coaches, teachers, and administrators
Built comprehensive data model supporting district/school/teacher hierarchies, coaching cycles, goals, check-ins, and lesson plans
Implemented privacy-first architecture with visibility flags (coach-only, shared, admin-visible) and FERPA/COPPA compliance considerations
Created teacher invite system with secure token-based onboarding
Integrated Cloudflare R2 for artifact storage with presigned URLs
Designed warm, approachable UI with terracotta brand palette suited for education professionals
Built responsive dashboard views for tracking coaching relationships and teacher progress
Deployed to Vercel with PostgreSQL database via Prisma ORM
projects.impact: Created a purpose-built tool for instructional coaches who currently rely on spreadsheets and scattered documents. CoachDesk centralizes teacher tracking, artifacts, and reporting while respecting the trust-based nature of coaching relationships through thoughtful privacy controls.
projects.skills: Next.js, React, TypeScript, PostgreSQL, Prisma, NextAuth.js, Cloudflare R2, Tailwind CSS, role-based access control, privacy-first architecture

projects.title: CodeTale
projects.challenge: Create an educational platform that teaches computational thinking to children ages 8-14 through game creation, grounded in learning science research and featuring AI-guided instruction.
whatIDid: Designed and developed Next.js web application with research-backed pedagogy for teaching computational thinking
Created Cappy, an AI capybara mascot with 6 animated states that guides students through game creation
Built two game creation paths: Adventure (story-driven point-and-click) and Action (tile-based dungeon games)
Implemented three difficulty levels (Explorer, Creator, Coder) based on Zone of Proximal Development theory
Integrated Claude AI for content generation with explainable AI that teaches prompt engineering to kids
Developed visual game maps, guided debugging tools, and contextual learning moments
Applied cognitive load theory principles with step-by-step wizards and progressive feature disclosure
Created pixel art UI with Web Audio API sound feedback for child-friendly interaction
projects.impact: Built an educational tool that makes computational thinking accessible to elementary and middle school students. By combining game creation with AI assistance and research-backed pedagogy, CodeTale demonstrates how technology can teach kids not just to use AI, but to understand how to collaborate with it effectively.
projects.skills: Next.js, React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, Claude AI integration, learning science research, educational game design, cognitive load theory, constructionist learning

about.title: About
about.p1: I've spent my career at the intersection of education, technology, and equity.
about.p2: My mother is from Spain and my father from Puerto Rico. I grew up bilingual, living between two worlds. That dual perspective shapes everything I do - I see problems from multiple angles and build bridges between different communities, stakeholders, and ways of thinking.
about.p3: My journey in education started at Liberty Science Center in New Jersey, where I fell in love with the moment when a student's eyes light up understanding something new. From there, I moved through museum education, afterschool STEM programs, and eventually into K-12 schools.
about.p4: When New York City launched CS4All - the nation's most ambitious computer science equity initiative - I helped lead the work in Manhattan. Over three years, I watched teachers who'd never coded before become confident CS educators. I saw students from underrepresented communities discover talents they didn't know they had. That experience taught me that access isn't enough - you need systems, support, and a commitment to equity.
about.p5: Since then, I've worked at national scale leading CSforALL's SCRIPT initiative, designed coaching frameworks at Cornell Tech, and now serve as a Research Scholar at NC State's Friday Institute, managing SceneCraft - an AI-enhanced educational tool. In this role, I align research, design, and stakeholder collaboration to create data-informed learning solutions that respond to the evolving needs of students and educators. Each position has reinforced my belief that innovation spreads not through technology alone, but through relationships, trust, and translating between the languages of different stakeholder groups.
about.p6: Currently based in Durham, NC, I'm working at the intersection of AI and education while always looking to explore beyond the horizon. Throughout my career, I've built bridges: between researchers and practitioners, between policy makers and teachers, between US and international education systems, between corporate partners and school districts. I believe that quality of life matters, that community matters, and that you can do meaningful work from anywhere.
about.p7: I bring a strategic, community-driven approach to all aspects of my work, grounded in a commitment to educational equity, empathetic leadership, and the responsible integration of emerging technologies. Whether helping EdTech companies navigate new markets and partnerships, supporting schools in implementing innovative tools responsibly, or building coalitions that bridge different stakeholder ecosystems, I focus on creating sustainable, systemic change.
about.p8: I believe deeply that every student deserves access to powerful learning experiences, regardless of their background. That belief - alongside a focus on data-informed decision making and culturally responsive practices - has guided every program I've built and every partnership I've formed.
about.p9: If you're working on something that matters in education, I'd love to talk.

hero.title: Tech Sovereignty
hero.subtitle: Build your own networks. Control your own data. Own your digital future.
hero.description: A project-based curriculum teaching students and communities to build independent technology infrastructure—from local networks to self-hosted AI—breaking free from corporate tech dependency.

why.title: Why Tech Sovereignty?
why.intro: Giant tech companies extract our data, manipulate our attention, and make us dependent on systems we don't control. There's another way.

problem.title: The Problem
problem.description: Corporate platforms harvest personal data, use algorithms to manipulate behavior, and create dependency on expensive proprietary systems—especially harming low-income and marginalized communities.

vision.title: Our Vision
vision.description: Communities owning their own technology infrastructure: local networks, self-hosted services, and AI tools that serve people—not corporate profits.

benefit.title: The Benefit
benefit.description: Digital independence, data privacy, local economic power, and the skills to build and maintain technology that reflects community values.

curriculum.title: Project-Based Curriculum
curriculum.description: Learn by building. Each track takes you from fundamentals to real-world projects that serve your community.

networking.title: Networking Fundamentals
networking.description: Understand how the internet works and build your own networks from scratch.

project1.title: Build Your First Local Network
project1.description: Set up a home network with a router, switch, and multiple devices. Learn IP addresses, DHCP, and basic network troubleshooting.

project2.title: Understanding Internet Protocols
project2.description: Dive into TCP/IP, DNS, HTTP, and other protocols that make the internet work. Use packet sniffing tools to see data in motion.

project3.title: Creating a Mesh Network
project3.description: Build a resilient mesh network that doesn't depend on centralized infrastructure. Connect neighbors and share resources.

project4.title: Community Internet Infrastructure
project4.description: Design and plan a community-owned ISP or wireless network. Understand legal, technical, and organizational requirements.

selfHosted.title: Self-Hosted Services
selfHosted.description: Replace corporate cloud services with your own—keeping your data under your control.

project1.title: Set Up Your Own Server
project1.description: Transform an old computer or Raspberry Pi into a server. Learn Linux basics, remote access, and system administration.

project2.title: Self-Hosted Cloud Storage
project2.description: Deploy Nextcloud to replace Google Drive or Dropbox. Set up file sync, sharing, and collaborative documents.

project3.title: Community Communication Platform
project3.description: Set up Matrix/Element for secure, decentralized messaging. Create a communication hub for your community or organization.

project4.title: Local-First Applications
project4.description: Build and deploy applications that work offline and sync when connected. Understand the local-first software movement.

ai.title: AI/LLM Independence
ai.description: Run powerful AI models on your own hardware—no cloud required, no data leaving your community.

project1.title: Understanding AI Models
project1.description: Learn how large language models work, their capabilities and limitations, and the ethical considerations of AI deployment.

project2.title: Running Local LLMs
project2.description: Use Ollama or llama.cpp to run open-source AI models on your own computer. Compare performance and capabilities.

project3.title: Fine-tuning for Community Needs
project3.description: Customize AI models for specific community applications—local language, cultural context, or specialized knowledge.

project4.title: Building AI-Powered Tools
project4.description: Create practical applications using local AI: document assistants, translation tools, educational aids, or community resources.

appDev.title: App Development
appDev.description: Build applications that serve your community—social networks, resource directories, and tools for local organizing.

project1.title: Web Development Basics
project1.description: Learn HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. Build your first static websites and understand how the web works.

project2.title: Building Community Apps
project2.description: Create web applications with databases and user accounts. Build tools like event calendars, resource directories, or bulletin boards.

project3.title: Decentralized Social Networks
project3.description: Set up and customize federated social platforms like Mastodon. Understand ActivityPub and the fediverse.

project4.title: Mobile App Development
project4.description: Build mobile apps for iOS and Android using React Native or Flutter. Deploy apps that work offline.

community.title: Community Building
community.description: Technology is only as powerful as the community that uses it. Learn to teach, organize, and sustain.

project1.title: Teaching Tech in Your Community
project1.description: Design and facilitate workshops to share technical skills. Learn pedagogy, accessibility, and inclusive teaching practices.

project2.title: Connecting with Other Communities
project2.description: Build networks between communities doing similar work. Share resources, knowledge, and mutual support.

project3.title: Sustainable Tech Cooperatives
project3.description: Explore governance models, funding strategies, and organizational structures for community-owned technology.

project4.title: Collaborative Technology Governance
project4.description: Develop governance structures that keep technology accountable to community needs—policies, decision-making, and ethics.

q1.question: How do I choose the right curriculum for my school?
q1.answer: Consider your grade levels, teacher experience, available technology, and budget. Start with one grade band and expand gradually. Code.org and CS Unplugged are great entry points for schools new to CS.

q2.question: Do teachers need CS backgrounds to teach these curricula?
q2.answer: Most curricula are designed for teachers without CS degrees. They include comprehensive teacher guides, PD resources, and often free professional development. Bootstrap and Code.org offer particularly strong teacher support.

q3.question: How can I fund CS education in my district?
q3.answer: Many districts use Title I, Title II, or Title IV-A funds. ESSER funds have also supported CS initiatives. Additionally, many curricula are completely free, reducing implementation costs.

q4.question: What technology do we need?
q4.answer: Requirements vary by curriculum. CS Unplugged requires no computers. Scratch runs on Chromebooks and tablets. Some high school courses benefit from 1:1 devices. Check each curriculum's technical requirements.
